g.text: There is no evidence to support an effect from a
combination of several forms of prophylaxis.

Beta-blockers should normally be selected as the ﬁrst
among ﬁrst-line drugs. Evidence is strongest for propran-

150–200 mg a day in case of lack of effect. The typical
interval to a maximum of 120 mg
Frequently, an effect is achieved at 120–160 mg daily.
Once the dosage is established, a retard drug may be
introduced to increase compliance. Furthermore, there is
some evidence to support an effect of bisoprolol, timolol
reduced physical capacity and cool extremities; see Table
proate have a well-documented effect comparable to that of
beta-blockers, but are generally associated with more side
effects. The typical dosage for topiramate is 25 mg
increased by 25 mg at 14-day intervals to 100 mg/day
divided into two doses and, subsequently, dose adjustment
if needed to 50–200 mg divided into two doses. Side
effects include paraesthesias, sedation, dizziness, weight
loss, kidney stones and a range of cognitive side effects.
The typical dosage of valproate is 1,000 mg
some cases a subsequent dose adjustment to 500–1,800 mg

weight increase, affection of the liver, thrombocytopaenia

maceuticals are available, for which the evidence to sup-
port an effect is weaker or which have more side effects
than the mentioned ﬁrst-line medications. These pharma-
ceuticals are therefore categorised as second or third line;

mones). Candesartan has few side effects [
1, if necessary increasing to 24–32 mg a day.
Amitriptyline is particularly suitable if the patient also
intervals to 10–100 mg daily. The entire dose is given
1–2 h before bedtime. The typical dose needed to ensure an
optimal balance between effect and side effects is
30–50 mg daily. Pizotifen should be given as 0.5-mg doses
every third day to 1.5 mg nocte, possibly increasing to
3. Side effects include weight increase and fatigue.
Tension-type headache is characterised by a bilateral,
pressing pain of mild to moderate intensity. Such headache
is not associated with the typical migraine characteristics
such as aggravation by physical activity, vomiting or
severe nausea and sensitivity to light and sound. There
are three main types: (1) sporadic episodic tension-type
headache, (2) frequent episodic tension-type headache and
(3) chronic tension-type headache. The diagnostic criteria
for tension-type headache are shown in Table
Episodic tension-type headache which occurs no more than
a few times a month rarely causes concern and is often the
Prophylactic migraine medication, second- and third-line
